reviewText:
RollerCoaster Tycoon 3: Platinum Edition is a theme park sim-tycoon game. You are put in charge of a your own theme parks which you must expand to bring more customers and money to them.

Pros: You have a large variety of rollercoasters, rides, kiosks and themed decorations to lay, often more than you'll be able to cram in a single map. You manage the finance by determining costs for rides, food and souvenirs, balancing against running costs, staff wages other expenses including research which allow you to access even more rides and objects for your park. You start your career with a short selection of maps and a few pre-made rollercoaster designs, and unlock more as you achieve goals in each locations. The Soaked! and Wild! expansions adds even more locations, rides and stalls, you can play the same map over and over yet build different parks every time! Many rides allow themed-customization as well, from color scheme to cart-style or train-length. Micromanagement can also be as deep as you want it: you can go as far as choosing how much pickles a specific burger stand puts in its 1/4-pounder, or don't bother with it, it's up to you.

Cons: The graphics are bad when zoomed in, from character designs to fixed-shadows under moving objects, graphical glitches including bad character animations or placement on rides. You can barely hear the music from your rides unless you're zoomed in almost all the way. Building rides has flaws, too: buying a pre-made rollercoaster design never explains why a location wouldn't work or what can be done to the landscape to make it fit, while other times the entire ride will get elevated multiple stories due to a single tile that's 1 pixel higher than the others. As the first game of the series to drop the genre's usual fix-isometric view for a 3D-engline, the camera controls can be extremely clunky, while the vertical angle resets every time you're trying to change it.

Verdict: ★★★★☆ - Next on your list!

If you like tycoon games, you're likely to enjoy this one. I could write a review 10 times as long and still have more to say about this game, so in a nutshell: perfect example of a tycoon game done right, with huge variety, good flexibility and excellent replayabiliy. I look forward to the final version of RollerCoaster Tycoon World, the next entry in the franchise!

reviewText:
Chris Sawyer, maker of 90s clasic Transport Tycoon 2 Deluxe, was part of this revamp of RCT2 that does not add much in terms of graphics. This third installment of the game was made by Atari with the intention to attract all ages and genders, so the game looks slightly childish in my opinion. But make no mistake - this simulation is so rich it would make your head explode.

The game features an incredible level of depth to the simulation, almost unparallaled. It allows you to control if/how much toppings you put in each beverage sold in one of the dozens of stalls. It includes cheap terrain modification (and spray paint) and many differently themed decorations and buildings. It has a scheduled fireworks simulator with a built in looper (and the cost is per single firework). Each sim in the park has a wallet, a set of hands to hold on to stuff, a set of bars for hunger/thirst/nausea and ride preferences. You will, at some point, be required to address the career ambitions of Animal Keeper 17.

And there's the rollercoaster simulator. Many dozens of real rollercoasters where the ride excitement is a factor of the speed, drops, g forces and more. A beatutifully complex and simple interface. I grew up playing the prequels and I was surprised every ride and rollercoaster I knew from the game was a real thing somewhere. RCT2 had missions in Six Flags parks and other famous parks around the world. This one instead has many creative scenarios where you start with a crazy looking old town or a huge garden that show you what this game has to offer if you decide to go sandbox.

Which is probably the point of this game - it's like building models more than anything.

Downsides are the low difficulty in this installment. If you are completing the missions you don't really need to use the many features of this game. I would give my Peeps a food stall only after three or four months. There's no benefit to tampering with the food and items you sell (the ride control boxes are awesome to tinker with).

Buy it on sale for sure.

reviewText:
First of all, bear in mind that my low steam playtime is just that. I used to beat the crap out of the game disc on my first laptop, so you can easily add 80 hours to the playtime.

Well, RollerCoaster Tycoon 3 is now an aging beast. The game originally released in 2004, and that unfortunally shows. While graphics isn't the main or even secondary reason you would like to play this game, there are some now hard to forgive kinks in that department like the lack of native 1080p support. There are of course workarounds to this, but then again, it's hard to blame a game from before widescreens became common to have widescreen support.

So, what about the game itself? Well, it's really as solid as you would expect the sequel to RCT2 would be.  While the iconic, isometric pixel art of the first two games have been replaced with 3D, it really looks good for its age. There is content enough in the game to keep you sucked in for a long, long time, plenty of RollerCoaster types and designs to keep you interested and best of all, the people in the park aren't as timid as they were in the first two games, allowing you to build more extreme rides without it having a negative impact on your play.

So, why would you buy this? Honestly, Nostalgia is the main reason. But it does this very, very well and I still return to it ten years later.

reviewText:
8.5/10 - RollerCoaster Tycoon 3 Platinum is a soiid collection and the definitve package for the RollerCoaster Tycoon 3 series, as it features the base game, plus both expansions. The expansion which add a tremendous amount of content to the game. RCT3 is at its core, a management game. You build and run a theme park the way you see fit, byt placing rides, attractions, booths, and more, to attract customers, and at the end, collecting their hard earned money to keep the park going, and to pay your employees their hard earned money. Obstacles will come in the form of rides breaking down, unhappy patrons or employees, and more problems to solve. And there are 2 ways to play this game: Full on simulation mode, where money matters, or a full on sandbox mode, where you can pretty much spend as much as you want, and get away with anything. There are as well, fun little scenarios to play to get you used to the games mechanics, which start off as tutorials, and end up being challenges to help you unlock stuff.

For anyone who has played RCT1 and 2, this game strays from the earlier isometric visuals of the first 2, and comes back with full 3D visuals, which this time around actually let you ride the park rides in 1st person. Everything looks pretty damn gorgeous, except for a few visual hiccups, like when messing with terrain, or the extremely aged and ugly looking patrons. Everything else looks damn fine though for a game this old. The expansions will take your vanilla park, and add a water park features, as well as a wildlife park, complete with various animals to use as attractions for the patrons.

This title is pretty easy to get into, even for people new to management games. Also a blast to play for veterans.

reviewText:
It is a fun game, but be prepared to lose a lot of hours to it.  It is similar to Sim City in the sense that you are building stuff using tile placement and budgets.  It is fully 3D, has a lot of really nice content, and has some neat features, like the ability to actually ride the rides.  The only way the game could be better in my opinion is to allow you to run around in first-person mode and play the game as an employee.  I have seen that done before, but it has never been done well.  At least this game does everything else well.

There are no Steam achievements, but there are challenges within the game.  You can also customize the game greatly.  I also think the game's controls are decent and the graphics are pretty good.  The overall atmosphere feels similar to the county fair until you start building the big rides and hiring lots of employees.  Then, it feels more like an actual theme park, I guess.

There are some confusing mechanics, as well.  The menus are hard to navigate, and the pool system is bizarre.  You would think that pool paths would work like regular paths, but no, they work on their own menu.  To this day, I still cannot figure out how to connect a pool to the rest of the theme park.

reviewText:
Over the past five years, I've easily sunk more hours into this game than any other. While it's easy enough to jump into to get started, it can be very addictive and take over your life for a while with its depth and seemingly endless possibilities. I've never even messed around much with the money management or scenarios, and I'm still creeping up on 200 hours with this bad boy just on Steam, which is my second run with the game.

There are a few different routes you can take with RCT3. You can try to tackle all the scenarios and successfully manage some pre-built (or partially built) parks, create your own parks in sandbox mode without monetary restrictions, or sadistically terrorize the peeps in parks of pure mayhem. Any of these is a viable route to take, and reason enough to pick this up.

Of course, RCT3 isn't perfect. It's definitely showing its age at this point, the physics aren't remotely realistic, and the graphics (especially the peeps) are a bit cartoony. There are also some maddening limitations with the grid (I find your lack of diagonals disturbing), curious omissions from the pre-supplied content (no stock picnic tables?!), and many fans of the series seem to prefer the older games.

Despite the shortcomings, however, there's just too much here to like. Custom content has kept this game going for a decade now and has made up for a lot of those omissions. Being able to view your parks in 3D and ride" any of your rides is simply awesome the first time you experience it. And just being able to create your own amusement park -- a FULL park with flat rides

reviewText: This was my first RCT game when I was a kid and I enjoy it now as much as I did then. If I had a Steam account when this released, I'd have an unhealthy amount of hours docked on this game. The Wild and Soaked add-on packs are nice too, though the game is still just as fun without them. Your imagination is your own limitation in this game. The one very minor issue I have with RCT3 in general is the camera movement. It can be a bit of a pain at times when you're trying to build a coaster because it only shows from a downward angle and can only go flat when you middle mouse click and drag, then it holds it for a second and goes back to its original angle. The camera pan from left to right can sometimes get a little irritating as well. This didn't bother me so much as a kid a it does now (I use Maya for 3D animation and am used to moving the camera around in order to view all angles of whatever I'm building), however, it's not something worth condeming the game for. Overall, this game is very fun to play and I thoroughly enjoy everything it has to offer.
